commit_message:
Specification for review of oslo quota module

Change-Id: I7c459644ae61d1c503c550b8b2df3ad880a84094
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/oslo-specs refs/changes/27/132127/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. =================================== Review oslo-incubator quota module =================================== Launchpad url: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/oslo-incubator/+spec/review-quota-module The goal of the changes proposed in this specification is to improve the current quota oslo-incubator module to the point where it can be successfully used by most OpenStack projects which need to perform quota management. Problem description =================== Currently every OpenStack project does quota management and enforcement in its own way. While there are certainly good reasons for this, both technical and process-related, it is also true that the operations pertaining quota management and enforcement are common enough across projects that they could be abstracted out in a library or in their own service endpoint. An oslo-incubator library for dealing with quota enforcement is already present (``openstack.common.quota``) , even if currently not used by any project. This specification discusses improvements of the the oslo incubator library for quota enforcement. Quota management APIs are out of scope for this specification. The rest of this section discusses the existing quota library identifying areas for improvement. The library currently provides a "Quota Engine" responsible for quota enforcement, which relies on a driver for accessing quota/usage information and making reservations. The only driver currently provided is a "DB driver". This driver however requires a "DB API" object to be passed to its constructor, so the business logic for handling quotas, usage and reservation is not part of the driver itself. For instance, if this library were to be used with nova, most of the business logic will actually be contained in ``nova.db.sqlalchemy.api`` In particular the engine merely proxies resource reservation management operations to the driver, which in its turn does little more than calling the DB API routines supplied by the consumer application. This basically means that even if the quota module exposes methods for resource reservation, consumer applications must provide most of the business logic needed for making that work. Also, the quota engine exposes methods such as get_user_quotas or get_defaults which pertain more to the realm of quota management than enforcement. It might be worthwhile providing a cleaner separation of interfaces. Even if the current module provides the concept of a "Resource" as something which has a quota and a current usage (count), it seems this concept is not then used in the logic for making reservation and checking quota availability, which instead appears to rely on quota usage explicitly tracked using DB APIs. Proposed change =============== With this specification, the existing oslo quota module will be amended in a way such that it will be provide the following components: 1. Quota enforcement engine (Engine) This component performs quota availability checks, makes reservations, and manages them by committing, canceling, or expiring them 2. Quota data sources (DS) This components is in charge of providing an abstract interface for retrieving resource quotas and usage. It will also manage resource registration. The Engine relies on the DS to obtain information necessary for deciding when there is enough headroom to satisfy a request, and for making or canceling reservations. The engine however is oblivious of where the data retrieved by the DS are. They could be fetched from a database, read from a text file, or even retrieved through a remote call. The DS abstraction provides the level of flexibility required for enabling a single engine to work with different consumer applications which might store quota and usage information differently. :: +-------------------+ | | | | +-------------------+ reserVations +-----------+--+ | | <----------------> | | | Quota | usage | Quota | SqlAlchemy | | <----------------> data | data source | | Enforcement | quotas | source | | | <----------------+ | | +-^-------^-----+-^-+ +-----------+--+ | |check |reserve|commit | | | | | | | | | | +----^--^--^--^-----+ | | | | | | | | | | | | | | Quota data | | | | | | | model classes | | | | | | | | | | +----+--+--+--+-----+ | | +------------------------------+ | | +--------------------------------------| Consumer | +-------+--------------------------------------+ Application | | | +-------------------+ Quota enforcement engine details -------------------------------- The enforcement engine is the primary interface for consumer applications. It should expose the following operations: - headroom_check(project_id, user_id, resources) Tells how many items for each resource can be granted considering current usage and reservations. - reserve(project_id, user_id, expire_after, resource_request) Tries to reserve the specified amount of resources. An optional expiration time for the reservation can be specified. Consistently with current behaviour, raises if the request cannot be satisfied and the exception details will carry information about current headroom. Particular care should be taken to avoid races when making reservations. - commit(reservation_id) Commits a reservation. This implies deleting the reservation and updating usage data accordingly. The caller should invoke this method once the previously reserved resources have been created. - cancel(reservation_id) Cancels a reservation. This merely deletes the reservation. The caller should invoke this method if the operation for which the resources were reserved fails. - expire(reservation_ids) Removes a reservation if it is expired. If reservation_ids is not specified tries to remove all expired reservations. Returns the reservation which have been actually removed. In a way, this is not very different, at least at an interface level, from the QuotaEngine which is currently available. The interface is however simplified including only those operations which are needed for enforcing quotas. Quota data source details ------------------------- A data source holds information about: - Resources For each registered resource the data source will hold overall quota and current usage (both allocated and reserved) - Reservations A reservation is constituted by an identifier, an optional expiration timestamp, and a list of resource "asks" identified as (<Resource>, <num_requested>) tuples. Moreover, a reservation will also hold the identifier of the project (and optionally the user) who made it. Finally reservation objects will expose methods for removing or expiring a reservation Operations currently defined on the QuotaDriver interface can be easily transformed into data source operations. For instance: :: quota_get_all_by_project(project_id) would be equivalent to: [resource.quota for resource in ds.get_resources(project_id)] or: :: quota_usage_get_all_by_project(project_id) would be equivalent to: [resource.usage for resource in ds.get_resources(project_id].resources] and also: :: quota_usage_get_all_by_project_and_user(project_id, user_id) would be equivalent to: [resource.quota for resource in ds.get_resources(project_id, user_id)] The data source should also provide a transactional mode. This would allow to implement the reservation workflow as follows: Reserve: :: resv = Reservation(...) ds.reservations.add(resv) Commit: :: trans = ds.get_transaction() for resource in resv.resources: resource.update_usage(resv.resources[resource], transaction=trans) ds.reservations.remove(resv.id, transaction=trans) trans.commit() Data source implementations ------------------------------ Within the framework of this specification the only datasource which will be provided uses SqlAlchemy as a data persistence layer. Declarative data model classes for quota, quota usage and reservations must be passed to its constructor. The quota module therefore relies on data models which are provided by the consumer application, and does not add or alters any data model in it. However this means that the data source makes assumptions about the structure of the model classes, as they will be used to build queries. For instance, the Reservation data model should have project_id, user_id, and expire_ts attributes. While in general this is an acceptable requirement, it should be anyway possible to allow callers to supply mappings between expected attribute names and actual ones. The downside of this solution is that the datasource will need to resort to ``getattr`` and ``setattr`` to retrieve/set attributes on data models. Other data source implementations, such as one retrieving quota information from Keystone or any other centralized service might be supplied in the future. Alternatives ------------ First, one might think that quota management and enforcement should be performed in a dedicated service endpoint. This would make a lot easier to enforce quota checks for operations which require resources across several endpoints. For instance, a VM might need CPU and RAM resources from Nova, volume disk space from Cinder, and ports from Neutron. Blazar [1] implements this kind of functionality. Nevertheless, it also makes sense to provide a simpler option for enforcing quotas for deployers which do not wish to take advantage of a reservation service. For this reason the existence of a reservation service does not imply there is no reason for having a quota enforcement library. Passing a DB API object to the quota enforcement class is an obvious alternative to the "datasource" abstraction, and is also what happens with the current DB Quota driver. Similarly, a "db" object will be passed, and the quota enforcement engine will invoke the relevant methods on this object. The quota enforcement engine is still completely oblivious to the implementation of db operations. Although providing the quota enforcement engine with an object oriented data source seems a cleaner architectural choice, this appears a valid and viable alternative to the data source approach. The data source approach however has the advantage of being simpler from a maintainability perspective due to better encapsulation, and having an easier model for implementing transactional behaviour. The proposed change relies on data models supplied by the application consuming the library. It does not make any assumption about the storage backend or the persistency framework. A downside of this design choice is that the quota module is not 100% self contained, as the actual data models are provided by the consuming application. Alternatively, the quota module might provide the relevant data models, and the functions for operating on them (e.g: get_quota_by_project). This approach, albeit interesting, poses some challenges: - the library "augments" the consumer application's data model and should therefore provide the relevant DB migrations. How these migrations can be inserted into the consumer migration timeline is an open question (ie: the author of this spec has no idea at all). Also, Openstack projects could use sqlalchemy.migrate or alembic, therefore requiring oslo quotas to provide migration script for both. The general feeling here is that a library should avoid introducing data models as much as possible. - If the library is providing the data models, then it makes sense to do not only enforcement but also management for quotas in the library. Indeed, it would look rather weird if then a project's management layer operates on data models supplied by a third party library for creating tenant quotas or updating them. A project's quota API will probably become pretty much a proxy towards the quota library. This implicitly means that rather than a quota library, what we are trying to design is more a service for managing and enforcing quotas. This alternative has already been discussed earlier on in this section Keep current organization of code, which requires specific db api calls to be implemented. This works, but requires projects to expose such API. This will work fairly well with projects like Nova, but will require a good deal of work for projects like Neutron. Also a good chunk of the business logic for quota enforcement would still live in the projects' business logic. Moving this logic into the oslo quota module is actually one of the goals of this blueprint. Impact on Existing APIs ----------------------- This spec proposes backward-incompatible changes to the existing quota module. As it is currently not used by any project this should not constitute a problem. Security impact --------------- It is important that quota enforcement routines are reliable and not subject to race conditions which might allow tenants to gain more resource than what they're allowed to. Performance Impact ------------------ The time complexity of the resulting implementation should of the same order of the previous one. Therefore there should be no performance regression. Where possible, DB access will be also optimized. Configuration Impact -------------------- None. Developer Impact ---------------- Once ready, other Openstack project at some point will decide whether to switch to the oslo-incubator quota module. Upon doing so it might be necessary to perform changes in the way the consuming project handles quota enforcement, but these changes should generally result in a simplification of the project's logic. Testing Impact -------------- It is rather important to go beyond unit tests in the quota module. Functional testing to validate how the module will behave in a "real" context should be provided. Validation in integrated gate tests should be achieved by enabling this quota module in other openstack projects. Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- 1, salv-orlando 2. anybody else who would like to help Milestones ---------- All work items should be completed by Kilo-2. The Kilo-3 timeframe should be used for validation, testing, and adoption. Work Items ---------- 1. Define the data source interface and classes managed by data sources 2. Implement the SqlAlchemy data source 3. Implement the Quota Engine 4. Experiment with early adopters; validate with experimental gate job. Candidates for early adoption: neutron, nova Incubation ========== Adoption -------- For initial validation Neutron will be an adopter of this library. Nova and Cinder are also ideal candidates since the quota module currently available in the incubator is derived from quota management in these projects. Library ------- This project should graduate in a oslo.quota library. It seems there is no suitable graduated library where quota enforcement can live. Anticipated API Stabilization ----------------------------- At least one incubation release cycle is needed for stabilization and graduation. Two cycles are recommended. Documentation Impact ==================== This specification should imply only a small number of changes will be needed in admin and user documentation. Dependencies ============ None. References ========== [1] https://wiki.openstack.org/wiki/Blazar .. note:: This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode

commit_message:
Support py34 in Kuryr

The following patch introduces py34 in tox and updates
the test cases to support py34 related changes.

Change-Id: I5739cc1e3e42b10224c75fc3f936708c87574107

commit_message:
Docs/Reno: Updated repo build process

This release note explains the improvements around the repo build
process.

Closes-bug: 1509115

Change-Id: I692eb206b1831fd7e857cd5a97e5f7742d59bf37
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/openstack-ansible refs/changes/89/277689/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: --- prelude: > The repo build process in Mitaka no longer uses ``yaprt``. This has simplified the repo build process. features: - Repeatable deployments are now easier since the manifest files for OpenStack software uses the exact content from an upstream repository. Specific commits or tags can be referenced within the manifest. other: - The ``repo-store-source.yml`` playbook has been removed as it is no longer needed.

commit_message:
L3: enable plugin to decide if subnet is mandatory

Commit 07077bebb69da29994257d061d3a8d7ea9598c3d removed
enforcing that a subnet should be defined on a network. In
the case of IPv6 this is cool, but for V4 it is problematic.

The patch adds in a callback that enables the plugin to
determine validation policy.

The callback will be invoked prior to creating the gateway
port.

Closes-bug: #1543012

Change-Id: Idb7eeb5e0071aa5a2f302fba083504c4582edc1a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/neutron refs/changes/07/277307/4 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: if not subnets: msg = _('No subnet defined on network %s') % new_network_id raise exceptions.InvalidInput(error_message=msg)

commit_message:
Identity V3: missing api coverage for 'Get Endpoint' method

add missing test for the following method
https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/keystone-specs/api/v3/identity-api-v3.html#get-endpoint

Change-Id: I4f5a10b3cedf423d1bd908886ffcf44a5c23928c
Closes-Bug: #1536725

added_lines: @test.idempotent_id('7632a381-b683-4fc3-8ef2-29094ebccbe2') def test_get_endpoint(self): # Create an endpoint and get its attributes # Creating service s_name = data_utils.rand_name('service') s_type = data_utils.rand_name('type') s_description = data_utils.rand_name('description') new_service = ( self.services_client.create_service( name=s_name, type=s_type, description=s_description)) new_service = new_service['service'] self.service_ids.append(new_service['id']) # creating endpoint region = data_utils.rand_name('region') url = data_utils.rand_url() interface = 'public' new_endpoint = ( self.client.create_endpoint( service_id=new_service['id'], interface=interface, url=url, region=region, enabled=False)['endpoint']) self.addCleanup(self.client.delete_endpoint, new_endpoint['id']) actual_endpoint =\ self.client.get_endpoint(new_endpoint['id'])['endpoint'] # Asserting if the attributes of endpoint are the same self.assertEqual(new_service['id'], actual_endpoint['service_id']) self.assertEqual(interface, actual_endpoint['interface']) self.assertEqual(url, actual_endpoint['url']) self.assertEqual(region, actual_endpoint['region']) self.assertEqual(False, actual_endpoint['enabled'])

index exception.

(cherry picked from commit 7fa4e7d2ec998a2dab7327e539d3e581975cc50d)

subject: Top 100 slow tests: api.openstack.compute.test_api
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-02-07 22:44:31.000000000', 'files': ['nova/tests/unit/api/openstack/compute/test_api.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/commit/9fbe683bf712fb374d7af25397a61b65a653c147', 'message': 'Top 100 slow tests: api.openstack.compute.test_api

Three of the api tests show up in the top 100 slow unit tests:

    http://paste.openstack.org/show/485806/

These tests create a bunch fake WSGI apps, each costing as much as 0.5
seconds. This patch reduces the cost of creating those fakes by using
the init_only option, and stubbing out extension loading. It also
reduces the number of fakes created (see ncalls).

$ tox -e py27 nova.tests.unit.api.openstack.compute.test_api.APITest

Before:

   total runtime: 18.5453 sec

   ncalls  tottime  percall  cumtime  percall filename:lineno(function)
       24    0.001    0.000    9.752    0.406 fakes.py:67(wsgi_app)

   ncalls  tottime  percall  cumtime  percall filename:lineno(function)
       12    0.000    0.000    6.445    0.537 fakes.py:89(wsgi_app_v21)

After:

   total runtime: 0.8630 sec

   ncalls  tottime  percall  cumtime  percall filename:lineno(function)
        3    0.000    0.000    0.051    0.017 fakes.py:67(wsgi_app)

   ncalls  tottime  percall  cumtime  percall filename:lineno(function)
        3    0.000    0.000    0.064    0.021 fakes.py:89(wsgi_app_v21)

Change-Id: Ie56e0f3dbdab4b6324c152915dfad5ae668a3fe9
'}]
commit_message:
Top 100 slow tests: api.openstack.compute.test_api

Three of the api tests show up in the top 100 slow unit tests:

    http://paste.openstack.org/show/485806/

These tests create a bunch fake WSGI apps, each costing as much as 0.5
seconds. This patch reduces the cost of creating those fakes by using
the init_only option, and stubbing out extension loading. It also
reduces the number of fakes created (see ncalls).

$ tox -e py27 nova.tests.unit.api.openstack.compute.test_api.APITest

Before:

   total runtime: 18.5453 sec

   ncalls  tottime  percall  cumtime  percall filename:lineno(function)
       24    0.001    0.000    9.752    0.406 fakes.py:67(wsgi_app)

   ncalls  tottime  percall  cumtime  percall filename:lineno(function)
       12    0.000    0.000    6.445    0.537 fakes.py:89(wsgi_app_v21)

After:

   total runtime: 0.8630 sec

   ncalls  tottime  percall  cumtime  percall filename:lineno(function)
        3    0.000    0.000    0.051    0.017 fakes.py:67(wsgi_app)

   ncalls  tottime  percall  cumtime  percall filename:lineno(function)
        3    0.000    0.000    0.064    0.021 fakes.py:89(wsgi_app_v21)

Change-Id: Ie56e0f3dbdab4b6324c152915dfad5ae668a3fe9

commit_message:
libvirt: Make behavior of os_require_quiesce consistent

Currently, os_require_quiesce metadata is used in two meanings.
For volume backed instances, quiescing is always tried on
snapshot, and the metadata specifies whether snapshot should
be aborted if quiescing is failed. For image backed instances
in the libvirt driver, the metadata determines whether quiescing
is invoked or not.

To make the behaviors consistent, this introduces the same logic
as volume backed instances into libvirt image snapshotting.

This also fixes AttributeError during live snapshot introduced by
commit 4f43bbafa4bfc2ab149d5db4eb55320c1602658b.

Change-Id: Iade076c996118e53d085ede9574cdf01c9e97829
Closes-Bug: #1436579
Closes-Bug: #1488565

added_lines: img_meta = {"properties": {"hw_qemu_guest_agent": "yes"}} img_meta = {"properties": {"hw_qemu_guest_agent": "yes"}} def _test_live_snapshot(self, can_quiesce=False, require_quiesce=False): instance = objects.Instance(**self.test_instance) image_meta = {} if require_quiesce: image_meta = {'properties': {'os_require_quiesce': 'yes'}} mock.patch.object(drvr, '_set_quiesced') mock_chown, mock_snapshot, mock_quiesce): if not can_quiesce: mock_quiesce.side_effect = \ exception.InstanceQuiesceNotSupported( instance_id=instance.id, reason='test') drvr._live_snapshot(self.context, instance, mock_dom, srcfile, dstfile, "qcow2", image_meta) mock_quiesce.assert_any_call(mock.ANY, instance, mock.ANY, True) if can_quiesce: mock_quiesce.assert_any_call(mock.ANY, instance, mock.ANY, False) def test_live_snapshot(self): self._test_live_snapshot() def test_live_snapshot_with_quiesce(self): self._test_live_snapshot(can_quiesce=True) def test_live_snapshot_with_require_quiesce(self): self._test_live_snapshot(can_quiesce=True, require_quiesce=True) def test_live_snapshot_with_require_quiesce_fails(self): self.assertRaises(exception.InstanceQuiesceNotSupported, self._test_live_snapshot, can_quiesce=False, require_quiesce=True)
deleted_lines: img_meta = {"properties": {"hw_qemu_guest_agent": "yes", "os_require_quiesce": "yes"}} img_meta = {"properties": {"hw_qemu_guest_agent": "yes", "os_require_quiesce": "yes"}} def test_live_snapshot(self): mock_chown, mock_snapshot): drvr._live_snapshot(self.context, self.test_instance, mock_dom, srcfile, dstfile, "qcow2", {})

commit_message:
Launch Instance - Create Keypair Service

This patch includes a service that creates a keypair and returns
a promise that checks if the keypair was created successfully.

Co-Authored-By: Matt Borland <matt.borland@hpe.com>

Partially Implements: blueprint launch-instance-download-keypair-redesign
Change-Id: I3da0b8bde37b004df42f044887faeabe189af57f
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/horizon refs/changes/30/261130/5 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: (function () { 'use strict'; /** * @ngdoc overview * @name horizon.dashboard.project.workflow.keypair * * @description * Service to handle creating and downloading a keypair. */ angular .module('horizon.dashboard.project.workflow.launch-instance') .factory('horizon.dashboard.project.workflow.launch-instance.keypair.create-keypair-service', createKeypairService); createKeypairService.$inject = [ '$document', 'horizon.app.core.openstack-service-api.nova', '$q' ]; /** * @ngdoc service * @name CreateKeypairService * * @description * This service encapsulates the actions required to create * and download a keypair */ function createKeypairService($document, novaAPI, $q) { var service = { createAndDownloadKeypair: createAndDownloadKeypair }; return service; //////////////////////////// function createAndDownloadKeypair(name) { addDOMResource(name); return verifyKeypairCreation(name); } function addDOMResource(keypairName) { var url = constructKeyPairDownloadUrl(keypairName); $document.find('body').append( "<iframe id=" + keypairName + " src='" + url + "' style='display: none;' ></iframe>" ); } function verifyKeypairCreation(name) { return $q(function(resolve, reject) { $document.find('#' + name).load(function() { novaAPI.getKeypairs().then(function (response) { var foundKeypairs = response.data.items.filter(function sameName(item) { return item.keypair.name === name; }); if (foundKeypairs.length === 1) { resolve(foundKeypairs[0].keypair); } else { reject(); } }); }); }); } function constructKeyPairDownloadUrl(keyPairName) { return "/api/nova/keypairs/" + keyPairName + "/generate/"; } } })();

commit_message:
Log more info when mke2fs fails on a guest

We have a device not found issue, but it's unclear if the device
doesn't exist at all, or it's in the wrong place. When we fail, dump
out the contents of /dev for further review.

Change-Id: I8b66b8acadc1d50a5ea7befd5ca6874c1dedcb4e

commit_message:
Top 100 slow tests: legacy_v2.test_servers

These tests create a couple fake WSGI apps, each costing more than 0.5
seconds. This patch reduces the cost of creating those fakes to about
0.01 seconds by using the init_only option and stubbing out extension
loading.

Change-Id: Ibb6718d927f9eb2acc4c5ec935e9bbb99c402c49
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/nova refs/changes/11/277211/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: @property def wsgi_app(self): with mock.patch.object(extensions.ExtensionManager, 'load_extension'): # patch load_extension because it's expensive in fakes.wsgi_app return fakes.wsgi_app(init_only=('servers',)) res = req.get_response(self.wsgi_app) res = req.get_response(self.wsgi_app)
deleted_lines: res = req.get_response(fakes.wsgi_app()) res = req.get_response(fakes.wsgi_app())

commit_message:
Top 100 slow tests: api.openstack.compute.test_volumes

The volume tests are slow. They account for 7 of the top 100 slow unit
tests:

    http://paste.openstack.org/show/485806/

These tests create a bunch fake WSGI apps, each costing as much as 0.6
seconds. This patch reduces the cost of creating those fakes by using
the init_only option. It also reduces the number of fake WSGI apps
created (see ncalls).

$ tox -e py27 nova.tests.unit.api.openstack.compute.test_volumes

Before:

   total runtime: 20.9060 sec

   ncalls  tottime  percall  cumtime  percall filename:lineno(function)
       22    0.001    0.000    1.891    0.086 fakes.py:67(wsgi_app)

   ncalls  tottime  percall  cumtime  percall filename:lineno(function)
       10    0.000    0.000    6.020    0.602 fakes.py:89(wsgi_app_v21)

After:

   total runtime: 7.0804 sec

   ncalls  tottime  percall  cumtime  percall filename:lineno(function)
        9    0.000    0.000    0.297    0.033 fakes.py:67(wsgi_app)

   ncalls  tottime  percall  cumtime  percall filename:lineno(function)
        7    0.000    0.000    0.470    0.067 fakes.py:89(wsgi_app_v21)

Change-Id: I87845cd2c514c64e42201c7b99381ea63635afe7

commit_message:
OpenstackClient plugin for template show

This change implements the 'openstack stack template show' command.

Blueprint: heat-support-python-openstackclient

Change-Id: I4a832435e692fb92a169d01a9e95c5c083c49531
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/python-heatclient refs/changes/01/267701/10 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: import yamlfrom heatclient.common import template_formatfrom heatclient.tests import inline_templates class TestStackTemplateShow(TestStack): fields = ['heat_template_version', 'description', 'parameter_groups', 'parameters', 'resources', 'outputs'] def setUp(self): super(TestStackTemplateShow, self).setUp() self.cmd = stack.TemplateShowStack(self.app, None) def test_stack_template_show_full_template(self): arglist = ['my_stack'] self.stack_client.template = mock.MagicMock( return_value=yaml.load(inline_templates.FULL_TEMPLATE, Loader=template_format.yaml_loader)) parsed_args = self.check_parser(self.cmd, arglist, []) columns, outputs = self.cmd.take_action(parsed_args) self.assertEqual(self.fields, columns) self.assertEqual('2016-04-08', outputs[0]) def test_stack_template_show_short_template(self): arglist = ['my_stack'] self.stack_client.template = mock.MagicMock( return_value=yaml.load(inline_templates.SHORT_TEMPLATE, Loader=template_format.yaml_loader)) parsed_args = self.check_parser(self.cmd, arglist, []) columns, outputs = self.cmd.take_action(parsed_args) self.assertEqual(['heat_template_version', 'resources'], columns) self.assertEqual('2016-04-08', outputs[0]) def test_stack_template_show_not_found(self): arglist = ['my_stack'] self.stack_client.template = mock.MagicMock( side_effect = heat_exc.HTTPNotFound) parsed_args = self.check_parser(self.cmd, arglist, []) self.assertRaises(exc.CommandError, self.cmd.take_action, parsed_args)

commit_message:
OpenStackClient plugin for stack output list

This change implements the 'openstack stack output list' command.

Blueprint: heat-support-python-openstackclient

Change-Id: I1ca54c47076c7216106fb1c938107cf9016e968d

added_lines: class TestStackOutputList(TestStack): response = {'outputs': [{'output_key': 'key1', 'description': 'desc1'}, {'output_key': 'key2', 'description': 'desc2'}]} def setUp(self): super(TestStackOutputList, self).setUp() self.cmd = stack.OutputListStack(self.app, None) self.stack_client.output_list = mock.MagicMock( return_value=self.response) self.stack_client.get = mock.MagicMock( return_value=stacks.Stack(None, self.response)) def test_stack_output_list(self): arglist = ['my_stack'] parsed_args = self.check_parser(self.cmd, arglist, []) columns, outputs = self.cmd.take_action(parsed_args) self.stack_client.output_list.assert_called_with('my_stack') def test_stack_output_list_no_list(self): arglist = ['my_stack'] self.stack_client.output_list.side_effect = heat_exc.HTTPNotFound parsed_args = self.check_parser(self.cmd, arglist, []) columns, outputs = self.cmd.take_action(parsed_args) self.stack_client.output_list.assert_called_with('my_stack') self.stack_client.get.assert_called_with('my_stack') def test_stack_output_list_not_found(self): arglist = ['my_stack'] self.stack_client.output_list.side_effect = heat_exc.HTTPNotFound self.stack_client.get.side_effect = heat_exc.HTTPNotFound parsed_args = self.check_parser(self.cmd, arglist, []) self.assertRaises(exc.CommandError, self.cmd.take_action, parsed_args)

commit_message:
Dont pass xattrs to tar if its unsupported

On precise tar does not have xattrs support. Precise can still build
some image types, so lets not prevent it from doing so.

Change-Id: I268a8c2714ccd6c61e1cb7c5e3dfeab27cac1482

commit_message:
pip install -r requirements.txt is not necessary in Ubuntu 14.04

On Ubuntu 14.04, when you run python setup.py from the directory
of Swift, the setuptools will parse requirements.txt and install
packages if needed.

Please note, thanks to the good advices by Kota Tsuyuzaki, the
purpuse of this commit have changed.

Change-Id: I1537791759e5df749afa8fb48f580471c8e539bd
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/swift refs/changes/46/277146/2 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
deleted_lines: Ubuntu 12.04 users need to install python-swiftclient's dependencies before the installation of python-swiftclient. This is due to a bug in an older version of setup tools:: cd $HOME/python-swiftclient; sudo pip install -r requirements.txt; sudo python setup.py develop; cd -

commit_message:
Eventlet library no longer used

Eventlet used to be used in the openstack/common directory we had.  Since we've
removed that directory we don't need the requirement anymore.

Change-Id: Ib64a6cb900afeb18bd8c3f49fb354a63d086c2b4
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/monasca-persister refs/changes/14/278014/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Rework cluster-policy service api unit test

This patch reworks the cluster-policy unit test in engine service. The
goal is to make unit tests only focus on unit tests, not functional
tests.

Change-Id: I7388e23074e02fe112b8e628a3d1b38f62aa5794
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/senlin refs/changes/79/277879/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from senlin.common import consts from senlin.common import exception as excfrom senlin.engine import cluster_policy as cp_mod @mock.patch.object(service.EngineService, 'cluster_find') @mock.patch.object(cp_mod.ClusterPolicy, 'load_all') def test_cluster_policy_list(self, mock_load, mock_find): x_obj = mock.Mock(id='FAKE_CLUSTER') mock_find.return_value = x_obj b1 = mock.Mock() b1.to_dict.return_value = {'k': 'v1'} b2 = mock.Mock() b2.to_dict.return_value = {'k': 'v2'} mock_load.return_value = [b1, b2] result = self.eng.cluster_policy_list(self.ctx, 'CLUSTER') self.assertEqual([{'k': 'v1'}, {'k': 'v2'}], result) mock_find.assert_called_once_with(self.ctx, 'CLUSTER') mock_load.assert_called_once_with(self.ctx, 'FAKE_CLUSTER', filters=None, sort=None) @mock.patch.object(service.EngineService, 'cluster_find') def test_cluster_policy_list_cluster_not_found(self, mock_find): mock_find.side_effect = exc.ClusterNotFound(cluster='Bogus') @mock.patch.object(service.EngineService, 'cluster_find') @mock.patch.object(cp_mod.ClusterPolicy, 'load_all') def test_cluster_policy_list_empty(self, mock_load, mock_find): x_obj = mock.Mock(id='FAKE_CLUSTER') mock_find.return_value = x_obj mock_load.return_value = [] result = self.eng.cluster_policy_list(self.ctx, 'CLUSTER') self.assertEqual([], result) mock_find.assert_called_once_with(self.ctx, 'CLUSTER') mock_load.assert_called_once_with(self.ctx, 'FAKE_CLUSTER', filters=None, sort=None) @mock.patch.object(service.EngineService, 'cluster_find') @mock.patch.object(cp_mod.ClusterPolicy, 'load_all') def test_cluster_policy_list_with_params(self, mock_load, mock_find): x_obj = mock.Mock(id='FAKE_CLUSTER') mock_find.return_value = x_obj mock_load.return_value = [] result = self.eng.cluster_policy_list(self.ctx, 'CLUSTER', filters='FOO', sort='BAR') self.assertEqual([], result) mock_find.assert_called_once_with(self.ctx, 'CLUSTER') mock_load.assert_called_once_with(self.ctx, 'FAKE_CLUSTER', filters='FOO', sort='BAR') @mock.patch.object(service.EngineService, 'cluster_find') @mock.patch.object(service.EngineService, 'policy_find') @mock.patch.object(cp_mod.ClusterPolicy, 'load') def test_cluster_policy_get(self, mock_load, mock_policy, mock_cluster): mock_cluster.return_value = mock.Mock(id='FAKE_CLUSTER') mock_policy.return_value = mock.Mock(id='FAKE_POLICY') x_binding = mock.Mock() x_binding.to_dict.return_value = {'foo': 'bar'} mock_load.return_value = x_binding result = self.eng.cluster_policy_get(self.ctx, 'C1', 'P1') self.assertEqual({'foo': 'bar'}, result) mock_cluster.assert_called_once_with(self.ctx, 'C1') mock_policy.assert_called_once_with(self.ctx, 'P1') mock_load.assert_called_once_with(self.ctx, 'FAKE_CLUSTER', 'FAKE_POLICY') @mock.patch.object(service.EngineService, 'cluster_find') def test_cluster_policy_get_cluster_not_found(self, mock_find): mock_find.side_effect = exc.ClusterNotFound(cluster='Bogus') ex = self.assertRaises(rpc.ExpectedException, self.eng.cluster_policy_get, self.ctx, 'Bogus', 'POLICY') self.assertEqual(exc.ClusterNotFound, ex.exc_info[0]) self.assertEqual("The cluster (Bogus) could not be found.", six.text_type(ex.exc_info[1])) mock_find.assert_called_once_with(self.ctx, 'Bogus') @mock.patch.object(service.EngineService, 'cluster_find') @mock.patch.object(service.EngineService, 'policy_find') def test_cluster_policy_get_policy_not_found(self, mock_policy, mock_cluster): mock_cluster.return_value = mock.Mock(id='FAKE_CLUSTER') mock_policy.side_effect = exc.PolicyNotFound(policy='Bogus') ex = self.assertRaises(rpc.ExpectedException, self.eng.cluster_policy_get, self.ctx, 'CLUSTER', 'Bogus') self.assertEqual(exc.PolicyNotFound, ex.exc_info[0]) self.assertEqual("The policy (Bogus) could not be found.", six.text_type(ex.exc_info[1])) mock_cluster.assert_called_once_with(self.ctx, 'CLUSTER') mock_policy.assert_called_once_with(self.ctx, 'Bogus') @mock.patch.object(service.EngineService, 'cluster_find') @mock.patch.object(service.EngineService, 'policy_find') @mock.patch.object(cp_mod.ClusterPolicy, 'load') def test_cluster_policy_get_binding_not_found(self, mock_load, mock_policy, mock_cluster): err ex = self.assertRaises(rpc.ExpectedException, self.eng.cluster_policy_get, self.ctx, 'CLUSTER', 'POLICY') self.assertEqual(exc.PolicyBindingNotFound, ex.exc_info[0]) self.assertEqual("The policy (POLICY) is not found attached to " "the specified cluster (CLUSTER).", six.text_type(ex.exc_info[1])) @mock.patch('senlin.engine.actions.base.Action') @mock.patch.object(service.EngineService, Change-Id: Ic8a382c210c4c55e82ed87ea648da0a31099bf23
'}]
commit_message:
Fine tune the HACKING.rst document

This patch proposes some syntax fixes to the HACKING documentation.

Change-Id: Ic8a382c210c4c55e82ed87ea648da0a31099bf23
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/senlin refs/changes/62/277162/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: - [S318] Use assertion ``assertIsNone(A)`` instead of ``assertEqual(A, None)`` or ``assertEqual(None, A)``. - [S319] Use ``jsonutils`` functions rather than using the ``json`` package directly. - [S320] Default arguments of a method should not be mutable.(implicitly) document the usage of said feature. When submitting a patch to a bug without a unit test, a new unit test should be added. If a submitted bug fix does have a unit test, be sure to add a new one that fails without the patch and passes with the patch.senlin/doc/source/developer/testing.txt.Behind the scenes, `tox` is running `ostestr --slowest`, but is set up such that you can supply any additional arguments to the `ostestr` command. For example, the following command makes `tox` to tell `ostestr` to add `--analyze-isolation` to its argument list::
deleted_lines: - [S318] Change assertEqual(A, None) or assertEqual(None, A) by optimal assert like assertIsNone(A) - [S319] Ensure that jsonutils.%(fun)s must be used instead of json.%(fun)s - [S320] Method's default argument shouldn't be mutable!(implicitly) document the usage of said feature. If submitting a patch for a bug that had no unit test, a new passing unit test should be added. If a submitted bug fix does have a unit test, be sure to add a new one that fails without the patch and passes with the patch.senlin/doc/source/testing.txt.Behind the scenes, `tox` is running `testr run --parallel`, but is set up such that you can supply any additional `testr` arguments that are needed by `tox`. For example, the following command makes `tox` to tell `testr` to add `--analyze-isolation` to its argument list:: It is also possible to run the tests inside of a virtual environment you have created, or it is possible that you have all of the dependencies installed locally already. In this case, you can interact with the testr command directly. Running `testr run` will run the entire test suite. `testr run --parallel` will run it in parallel (this is the default incantation tox uses.) More information about testr can be found at: http://wiki.openstack.org/testr

subject: Fix first argument of murano env-template-add-app
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-02-10 02:51:08.000000000', 'files': ['doc/cli-reference/source/murano.rst'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/openstack-manuals/commit/1b31cc9a417cffbf93294dd92c31910913969018', 'message': 'Fix first argument of murano env-template-add-app

First argument of murano env-template-add-app is not ENV_TEMPLATE_NAME
but ENV_TEMPLATE_ID. This patch fixes it.

Change-Id: I4de7670e7e2c476943b09d4a4510c285d811548c
Related-Bug: #1541200
'}]
commit_message:
Fix first argument of murano env-template-add-app

First argument of murano env-template-add-app is not ENV_TEMPLATE_NAME
but ENV_TEMPLATE_ID. This patch fixes it.

commit_message:
Allow user-data on amphora creation

Currently, Amphora configuration data is being sent as personality
files as considered by Nova and some providers have limitations
and must use cloud-init user-data.

This patch introduces a new config option to enable user-data.
If enabled the files that were built, such as the amphora config
and certificates for the agent, will be templated into a cloud-init
user-data script that loads the files as expected. After this we
need to restart the agent as cloud-init happens at a higher level
than service scripts. This does increase the boot time.

This is configurable so there is no impact if it's not needed.

Change-Id: I60fa87722302eee9d3d1fd6ff1b5b5b697a2406e
Closes-Bug: #1541231

commit_message:
Introducing parallel zoning

The main purpose of this is spec to introduce parallel zoning capability
for the ZoneManager, in order to support unique switch type combinations.
The efficiency of zoning would be improved over the current method of
sequential zoning.

Change-Id: Icdf5d43b0c341bffd108ac8c9c0e70cd6054a254
blueprint: zonemanager-parallel-zoning
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder-specs refs/changes/18/186918/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== Parallel Zoning for ZoneManager ========================================== https://blueprints.launchpad.net/cinder/+spec/zonemanager-parallel-zoning This spec introduces parallel zoning operations for multiple fabrics. This proposal for parallel zoning will provide zoning for fabrics using multiple unique zone drivers. Problem description =================== Currently the ZoneManager only allows sequential creation of zones across the switches for a single type of switch. It cannot zone across multiple unique switch types, ie. switch_type1/switch_type2 combination. Linear call down for the zone drivers to perform a zoning operation, limits all switches to use same zone driver. +----------------+ | fc_zone_manager| +-------+--------+ | v +----------------+ |brcd_zone_driver| +-------+--------+ | v +----------------+ |brcd_fc_zone_cli| +-------+--------+ This limitation of sequential zoning linearly increases the time necessary for deploying a VM with multiple initiator ports and or multiple switches. The algorithm for zoning(creation/deletion) is currently inefficient because of unnecessary fabric access for a single zoning operation. There are multiple accesses to a switch for EACH initiator passed to the ZoneManager. These accesses are for port and zone information. #Example of adding a zone: 2-fabric setup, target1 & target3 are connected to switch_type1 target2 & target4 are connected to switch_type2 initiator-target-map = { 'initiator1': ['target1', 'target2'], 'initiator2': ['target3', 'target4'} * On each fabric associated with a target_wwpn value for each initiator_wwpn, add_zones() will perform a pre-check, _get_active_zone_set(), which accesses each fabric for the active_zones. * Will perform a get_san_context, which also accesses the switch, for port connectivity Number of reads : 2 get_san_context(), 4 _get_active_zone_set() = 6 reads 3 reads per fabric Number of writes : 4 add_zones() = 4 writes 2 writes per fabric Proposed change =============== Zone switches in parallel. Zoning the switches concurrently would reduce the overall time required to create multiple zones. It would also allow different switch types to be paired. The ZoneManger would streamline the initialization of the fabric CLI clients from the registered fabrics. These CLI connections are held on the initialization of the fc_zone_manager class(). This provides us access to multiple fabric connections for parallel operations for the duration of the ZoneManager class. It would be necessary to abstract the zoning operations, such as add/delete zones to be generic for all switch types. The intermediary step, within zone driver, would be eliminated. ZoneManager performing zoning operations would perform all functionality checks and also call the corresponding switch_type's CLI commands directly for its function. +---------------+ | | |fc_zone_manager| | | +-+-----------+-+ | | v v +---------------+ +-----------------+ | | | | |brcd_fc_zone_cli |cisco_fc_zone_cli| | | | | +---------------+ +-----------------+ 1)Zone information gathering(_get_active_zone_set) would only need to be accessed once versus multiple times per initiator. 2)Accessing port information(get_san_context) would required half the time. 3)Writing to fabric(add_zones) would require half the time. #Example of adding zone: Number of reads : 2 _get_active_zone_set(), 2 get_san_context() = 4 reads 2 reads per fabric Number of writes : 1 add_zones() = 2 writes 1 writes per fabric * note: There are WILL ONLY be 2 get_active_zone_set() calls, once for each fabric, instead of a get_active_zone_set() for each initiator. Alternatives ------------ None Data Model Impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- None Security Impact --------------- N/A Performance Impact ------------------ Decreased time necessary for overall zoning operations. Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- None Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- Switch vendors will not have to provide anything for the changes. Implementation ============== Refer to proposed change Work Items ---------- Dependencies ============ None Testing ===== There need to be additional unit test cases for the supported functionality change Documentation Impact ==================== * Optional- Currently there is a Cisco and Brocade Fiber Channel Zone Driver page, which documents the configuration settings for connecting to a switch. Would be more accurate to rename as "Fiber Channel Zone Configuration" References ========== None

commit_message:
Change-since filter for resource retrieving

Blueprint: resource-change-since-filter
APIImpact

Change-Id: I6b13bb853c3aacf8fd99af4a16e5373013a1586a
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder-specs refs/changes/70/152770/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: .. This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode =========================================== Change-since filter for resource retrieving =========================================== Include the URL of your launchpad blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/cinder/+spec/resource-change-since-filt Cinder resources have created_at, updated_at and deleted_at attributes to record the operation timestamps. But currently we can only query resources operated at a given timestamp. It's helpful to add a change_since filter so we can retrieve resources operated during a specific period. Problem description =================== Cinder API only supports filtering resources by discrete values, even though cinder resources have timestamp fields, users can only query resources operated at given time, not during given period. Users may be interested in resources operated in a specific period for monitoring or statistics purpose but currently they have to retrieve and filter the resources by themselves. This change can bring facility to users and also improve the efficiency of timestamp based query. Proposed change =============== Introduce a new change_since filter for retrieving cinder resources. It accepts a timestamp and cinder will return resources whose update_at fields are later than this timestamp. Alternatives ------------ As discussed in 'Problem description' section, users can retrieve and then filter resources by themselves, but this approach is neither convenient nor efficient. Leaving filtering work to database can utilize the optimization of database engine and also reduce data transmitted from server to client. Data model impact ----------------- None REST API impact --------------- List API will accept new query string parameter change_since. Users can pass time to the list API url to retrieve resources operated since a specific time. Security impact --------------- None Notifications impact -------------------- None Other end user impact --------------------- Python cinder client may add help to inform users this new filter. Python cinder client support dynamic assigning search fields so it is easy for it to support this new filter. Performance Impact ------------------ As discussed in 'Alternatives' section, performance can be improved for timestamp based query. Other deployer impact --------------------- None Developer impact ---------------- None Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: caizhiyuan1@huawei.com Other contributors: TBD Work Items ---------- * Add API filter * Add related test Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Unit test to test if change_since filter can be correctly applied. Documentation Impact ==================== Update cinder API reference to introduce this new filter. References ========== None

commit_message:
Grouping Multi Backend Pool Aware Cinder Scheduler

In a multi backend scenario a user should be able to specify
specific list of backend providers with pool info which cinder
scheduler should use during volume creation.

This proposal is to allow users to specify a list of backend providers
along with the pool information in the volume_type for the scheduler
to pick from. This helps in efficient cinder scheduling based on
user defined volume properties.

Change-Id: I04a4a3f101af3b3e34c3e10b6418a352a815fe2c
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder-specs refs/changes/80/182980/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: This work is licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 3.0 Unported License. http://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/3.0/legalcode ========================================== Grouping Multi-Backend Pool Aware Cinder Scheduler ========================================== Include the URL of your launchpad blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/cinder/+spec/cinder-pool-aware-multi-backend-filter Cinder supports multiple backend providers, each can consist of several pools with different capabilities and capacities. Currently the cinder scheduling decisions are made based considering on the capabilities of all the storage backend providers. There is no way where the host can specify that user wants to use a specific list of backend-providers among the available pools for VM provisioning. And in such case scheduler should only pick-up the best resource based on the user specified list of backend-providers. Having such feature will enable workloads to be scheduled more adequately. Problem description =================== Proposed blueprint focuses on a user scenario where there exists multiple storage providers having several pools with different capabilities. And the user wants to schedule its volume creation with a given set of storage providers along with specific pools. For eg: Say if there are 2 storage backend providers provider1-pool1 and pool2 and provider2 with pool3. These are shared between test and development team Test wants to create all its volumes either from provider1-pool1 Development wants to create all its volumes from either provider1-pool2 or provider2-pool3 As per the current cinder design, the Scheduler will select the backend-provider which matches the capabilities and capacities for any request. However, this does not meet the needs of the teams in this example as they require extra filtering. Proposed changes =============== Currently cinder Volume type property can only specify one backend storage provider. This proposal is to allow users to specify a candidate list of backend providers along with the pool information. The Scheduler will use this information to select among these for the volume create request. Below is the proposed implementations:- Workitem 1: Currently we use the volume type extra spec property capabilities:volume_backend_name as a single key value for a single storage backend provider host. We can utilize the same property to specify the multiple backend provider information separated by comma. Example :- Existing Usage: "capabilities:volume_backend_name": "provider1#pool1" Proposed Usage: "capabilities:volume_backend_name": "provider1#pool1,provider2#pool3" There will be some code changes needed where we retrieve the above property to convert it into a list of backend providers. Work-Item 2: In Cinder Scheduler Driverfilter needs to be updated to check the host filter based on list of backend_providers passed in the volume type extra-spec properties. Alternatives ------------ None Data model impact ----------------- No DB schema change involved. REST API impact --------------- No Impact. Security impact --------------- NA Notifications impact -------------------- NA Other end user impact --------------------- NA Performance Impact ------------------ Scheduler filters will now use only the specific list instead of fetching the processing the host stats for all storage providers and pools. So it is more efficient. Other deployer impact --------------------- NA Developer impact ---------------- Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary Assignee: Chhavi Agarwal (chhagarw@in.ibm.com) Other Contributors: Shyama Venugopal (shyvenug@in.ibm.com) Work Items ---------- Workitem 1: Currently we use the volume type extra spec property capabilities:volume_backend_name as a single key value for a single storage backend provider host. We can utilize the same property to specify the multiple backend provider information separated by comma. Example :- Existing Usage: "capabilities:volume_backend_name": "provider1#pool1" Proposed Usage: "capabilities:volume_backend_name": "provider1#pool1,provider2#pool3" There will be some code changes needed where we retrieve the above property to convert it into a list of backend providers. Work-Item 2: In Cinder Scheduler Driverfilter needs to be updated to check the host filter based on list of backend_providers passed in the volume type extra-spec properties. Dependencies ============ None Testing ===== There need to be additional test cases for the supported functionality. Documentation Impact ==================== None References ========== None

commit_message:
Cinder Volume Performance and Health collection for cinder volume
drivers.

Change-Id: Ib243216110b415500d563d18626fef3d4aa319cf
Implements: blueprint cinder-volume-performance-health-stats-collection
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder-specs refs/changes/48/178748/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: ===================================================== Cinder Volume Performance and Health Stat Collection ===================================================== Include the URL of your launchpad blueprint: https://blueprints.launchpad.net/cinder/+spec/cinder-volume-performance-health\ -stats-collection Enable the collection of block storage driver volume performance and health val ue collection for use in ceilometer and horizon. Problem description =================== Cinder volume performance and health metrics are unavailable to the user. Use Cases ========= Viewing 3rd party storage provider volume performance in the horizon client to developers and end users Proposed change =============== Extend the current cinder-volume driver interface and cinder volume manager to support per-volume performance collection, per-volume health status, and driver instance health status (per array health). The initial volume performance metrics will be as follows: * .Read IOPS (IO/s). . .iops_read. * .Write IOPS (IO/s). . .iops_write. * .Read Throughput (KB/s). . .throughput_read. * .Write Throughput (KB/s). . .throughput_write. * .Read Latency (us). . .latency_read. * .Write Latency (us). . .latency_write. The initial volume health metrics will be as follows: * Vendor Volume Health - vendor_health OPERATIONAL.|.WARNING.|.CRITICAL. * Vendor Volume Substatus - vendor_substatus a vendor specific field to show status such as "Pool health degraded", "performance throttled due to QOS" The initial instance health metrics will be as follows: * Array Health Status - array_status * Array Health SubStatus -array_substatus If the cinder volume driver supports the .perf_collection. feature the cinder volume manager would define and add new periodic stats * Using the .@periodic_task decorator, every 15 seconds call a new cinder volume driver interface get_volume_performance_stats() * Using the .@periodic_task decorator, every 60 seconds call a new cinder volume driver interface get_volume_health_stats() * The existing get_volume_stats() call would have two new attributes added to its expected response object: o .array_status. o .array_substatus Alternatives ------------ An alternative method to retrieve this information would be to query nova for the volume performance. One downside querying this level for performance information is that it does not scale as well. If a volume is presented to multiple nova instances then each instance would need to be checked simultaneously and the values combined which would be both. Data model impact ----------------- cinder.objects.volume will be expanded with the following properties: .performance.: {.iops_read.: 0, .iops_write.: 0, .throughput_read.: 0, .throughput_write.:0, .latency_read.:0, .latency_write.:0} .vendor_health.: {.vendor_health.: .., .vendor_substatus.: ..} The DB will need a schema bump to support the new attributes. REST API impact --------------- Existing volume detail requests will be extended to show last known performance information: GET /v2/{tenant_id}/volumes/detail GET /v2/{tenant_id}/volumes/{volume_id} Will both contain an additional volume property .performance. containing 6 new attributes: * iops_read * iops_write * throughput_read * throughput_write * latency_read * latency_write in addition to a new property .vendor_health. containing the attributes: * vendor_status * vendor_substatus Example highlighted in the proposed api response below: { "volume": { "status": "available", "attachments": [], "links": [ { "href": "", "rel": "self" }, { "href": "", "rel": "bookmark" } ], "availability_zone": "nova", "bootable": "false", "os-vol-host-attr:host": "ip-10-168-107-25", "source_volid": null, "snapshot_id": null, "id": "5aa119a8-d25b-45a7-8d1b-88e127885635", "description": "Super volume.", "name": "vol-002", "created_at": "2013-02-25T02:40:21.000000", "volume_type": "None", "os-vol-tenant-attr:tenant_id": "0c2eba2c5af04d3f9e9d0d410b371fde", "size": 1, "metadata": { "contents": "not junk" }, "performance": { "iops_read": 1065,"iops_write": 20,"throughput_read": 50, "throughput_write": 10,"latency_read": 100,"latency_write": 50}, "vendor_health": {"vendor_status": "OPERATIONAL", "vendor_substatus":"none"} } } Security impact --------------- * Does this change touch sensitive data such as tokens, keys, or user data? No * Does this change alter the API in a way that may impact security, such as a new way to access sensitive information or a new way to login? No * Does this change involve cryptography or hashing? No * Does this change require the use of sudo or any elevated privileges? No * Does this change involve using or parsing user-provided data? This could be directly at the API level or indirectly such as changes to a cache layer. No * Can this change enable a resource exhaustion attack, such as allowing a single API interaction to consume significant server resources? Some examples of this include launching subprocesses for each connection, or entity expansion attacks in XML. No Notifications impact -------------------- New notifications will be created for ceilometer to consume. Meters: Name Type Unit Resource Origin Note volume.performance.iops.read Gauge IO/s Volume ID Notification Read IOPS volume.performance.iops.write Gauge IO/s Volume ID Notification Write IOPS volume.performance.throughput.read Gauge KB/s Volume ID Notification Read Tp volume.performance.throughput.write Gauge KB/s Volume ID Notification Write Tp volume.performance.latency.read Gauge KB/s Volume ID Notification Read Latc volume.performance.latency.write Gauge KB/s Volume ID Notification Write Latc Other end user impact --------------------- This change will impact python-cinderclient, the .show. volume details command will be expanded to list out the latest performance values with units. For Example: performance {.iops_read.: 1065,.iops_write.: 20, .throughput_read.: 50, .throughput_write.: 10,.latency_read.: 100: .latency_write.: 50} vendor_health {vendor_status: OPERATIONAL,vendor_substatus: none} Performance Impact ------------------ The volume manager will handle two additional periodic tasks for each cinder volume driver instance. Other deployer impact --------------------- For volumes which do not currently have a driver implementing the .perf_collection. feature: they will have no values placed into their volume object and no events will be placed on the queue for ceilometer. Those volumes will have 0 values in the db. For existing deployments a DB schema update will add 0 performance values to existing entries and null values into health properties.. Developer impact ---------------- If cinder volume drivers would like to implement the new metrics they would need to report back support for the .perf_collection. feature and implement the following methods: * get_volume_performance_stats(self, refresh, volume) return an object with an attribute for each volume name containing the performance data defined above. { {iops_read: 1065,iops_write: 20,throughput_read: 50,throughput_write: 10, latency_read: 100,latency_write: 50} } * get_volume_health_stats(self, refresh, volume) return an object for each volume name with the requested health information { {vendor_status: WARNING,vendor_substatus:"pool health degraded"} } * get_volume_stats() call would have two new attributes added to its expected response object: array_status, array_substatus Implementation ============== Assignee(s) ----------- Primary assignee: andrew-durbin Other contributors: richard-hedlind Work Items ---------- * Update cinder volume models * Implement DB upgrade/downgrade process in cinder.db.sqlalchemy.migrate_repo.versions.0xx_add_perf_and_health_stats * Add periodic tasks to cinder volume manager * Implement python-cinderclient changes Dependencies ============ None Testing ======= Unit tests will be implemented for all changes. Documentation Impact ==================== Block-storage API v2 http://developer.openstack.org/api-ref-blockstorage-v2.html Python-cinderclient http://docs.openstack.org/user-guide-admin/common/cli_manage_volumes.html References ========== Cinder.volume.driver http://docs.openstack.org/developer/cinder/api/cinder.volume.driver.html

subject: Fix variable scope issue in try-except
revisions:
[{'number': 1, 'created': '2016-02-04 11:43:43.000000000', 'files': [], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/41425c67b422d613883d337a8428752ee75f982e', 'message': 'Fix variable scope issue in try-except

Below piece of code is not correctly handling the scope of variable
'backup'

    https://github.com/openstack/cinder/blob/9299e7aebea42095fe1fa09b89d7297b5a53826e/cinder/backup/api.py#L274-L300

The first problem is as below

```
    try:
        ...
        backup = objects.Backup(context=context, **kwargs)
        ...
    except Exception:
            ...
            backup.destroy()
            ...
```

If object.Backup.__init__ raises exception, variable 'backup' won't
be assigned. However the cleanup code invokes backup.destroy(), which
results in an UnboundLocalError. The original exception of __init__
is dropped, instead UnboundLocalError is raised up-level. I know that
for now objects.Backup.__init__ doesn't have chance to raise
exception, but when writing code we should not rely on such
assumption.

The second problem is as below

```
    try:
        ...
        backup.create()
        ...
    except Exception:
            ...
            backup.destroy()
            ...
```

The backup.create() invokes DB. If an DB exception is raised,
backup.id won't be assigned. Any access to backup.id will result in
an "NotImplementedError: Cannot load 'id' in the base class".
However, when cleaning up, the backup.destroy() does access
backup.id. So we have the same problem as the above one, and the true
exception is overrode by NotImplementedError.

The root problem is that this piece of code is not handling scope of
variable 'backup' properly. Variable used in except clause generally
has larger scope than what is in try clause. However variable 'backup'
in the above code is first-assigned inside try clause, which is easy
to result in scope issue.

This patch fixes it by adding a first-assignment outside try clause,
and add a safe check in except clause. The added test cases, if run
on the original code, it will show how the above problem occurs.

I searched the entire code base. This is the only occurrence of the
above issue AFAIK.

Closes-Bug: #1541745
Change-Id: I0e55c342ac489ff1ef27c0597b6dcba588778a04
'}, {'number': 2, 'created': '2016-02-04 15:43:17.000000000', 'files': ['cinder/backup/api.py', 'cinder/tests/unit/test_backup.py'], 'web_link': 'https://opendev.org/openstack/cinder/commit/20d920b07625ec5780b3785035a0280c3b317ba4', 'message': 'Fix variable scope issue in try-except

```
        ...

            backup.destroy()
            ...
```

The first problem: if object.Backup.__init__ raises exception,

backup.destroy(), which results in an UnboundLocalError. The original
exception of __init__ is dropped, instead UnboundLocalError is raised
up-level. I know that for now objects.Backup.__init__ doesn't have
chance to raise exception, but when writing code we should not rely
on such assumption.

The second problem: backup.create() invokes DB. If an DB exception is
raised, backup.id won't be assigned. Any access to backup.id will
result in an "NotImplementedError: Cannot load 'id' in the base
class". However, when cleaning up, the backup.destroy() does access
backup.id. So we have the similar problem as the first one, and the
original exception is overrode by NotImplementedError.

This patch fixes it by adding a first-assignment outside try clause,
and add a safe check in except clause. The added test cases, if run
on the original code, it will show how the above problem occurs.

Closes-Bug: #1541745
Change-Id: I0e55c342ac489ff1ef27c0597b6dcba588778a04

commit_message:
Fix variable scope issue in try-except

Below piece of code in cinder.backup.api.API.create does not handle
the scope of variable 'backup' properly. In general variable used in
except clause has larger scope than what is in try clause.

```
    try:
        ...
        backup = objects.Backup(context=context, **kwargs)
        backup.create()
        ...
    except Exception:
            ...
            backup.destroy()
            ...
```

The first problem: if object.Backup.__init__ raises exception,
variable 'backup' won't be assigned. However the cleanup code invokes
backup.destroy(), which results in an UnboundLocalError. The original
exception of __init__ is dropped, instead UnboundLocalError is raised
up-level. I know that for now objects.Backup.__init__ doesn't have
chance to raise exception, but when writing code we should not rely
on such assumption.

The second problem: backup.create() invokes DB. If an DB exception is
raised, backup.id won't be assigned. Any access to backup.id will
result in an "NotImplementedError: Cannot load 'id' in the base
class". However, when cleaning up, the backup.destroy() does access
backup.id. So we have the similar problem as the first one, and the
original exception is overrode by NotImplementedError.

This patch fixes it by adding a first-assignment outside try clause,
and add a safe check in except clause. The added test cases, if run
on the original code, it will show how the above problem occurs.

Closes-Bug: #1541745
Change-Id: I0e55c342ac489ff1ef27c0597b6dcba588778a04
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/cinder refs/changes/79/276179/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: from oslo_db import exception as db_excfrom cinder.tests.unit import utils @mock.patch.object(api.API, '_is_backup_service_enabled', return_value=True) @mock.patch.object(db, 'backup_create', side_effect=db_exc.DBError()) def test_create_when_failed_to_create_backup_object(self, mock_create, mock_service_enabled): volume_id = utils.create_volume(self.ctxt)['id'] self.ctxt.user_id = 'user_id' self.ctxt.project_id = 'project_id' # The opposite side of this test case is a "NotImplementedError: # Cannot load 'id' in the base class" being raised. # More detailed, in the try clause, if backup.create() failed # with DB exception, backup.id won't be assigned. However, # in the except clause, backup.destroy() is invoked to do cleanup, # which internally tries to access backup.id. self.assertRaises(db_exc.DBError, self.api.create, context=self.ctxt, name="test_backup", description="test backup description", volume_id=volume_id, container='volumebackups') @mock.patch.object(api.API, '_is_backup_service_enabled', return_value=True) @mock.patch.object(objects.Backup, '__init__', side_effect=exception.InvalidInput( reason='Failed to new')) def test_create_when_failed_to_new_backup_object(self, mock_new, mock_service_enabled): volume_id = utils.create_volume(self.ctxt)['id'] self.ctxt.user_id = 'user_id' self.ctxt.project_id = 'project_id' # The opposite side of this test case is that a "UnboundLocalError: # local variable 'backup' referenced before assignment" is raised. # More detailed, in the try clause, backup = objects.Backup(...) # raises exception, so 'backup' is not assigned. But in the except # clause, 'backup' is referenced to invoke cleanup methods. self.assertRaises(exception.InvalidInput, self.api.create, context=self.ctxt, name="test_backup", description="test backup description", volume_id=volume_id, container='volumebackups')

commit_message:
Fix incorrect result of listing templates

- When user executes 'murano env-template-list', it only returns all
  templates belong this tenant, and doesn't include public templates
  from other tenants.
- It returns all templates belong to tenant when only requests
  private templates.

Change-Id: I50f70f28827c851139f74cff3923843c3d48170b
Closes-Bug: #1542626
Closes-Bug: #1540709

added_lines: def test_list_env_templates_with_different_tenant(self): """Create two template in two different tenants, test list public template from another tenant. """ self._set_policy_rules( {'create_env_template': '@', 'list_env_templates': '@'} ) self.expect_policy_check('create_env_template') body = {'name': 'mytemp', 'is_public': False} req = self._post('/templates', json.dumps(body), tenant='first_tenant') result = req.get_response(self.api) self.assertFalse(json.loads(result.body)['is_public']) self.expect_policy_check('create_env_template') body = {'name': 'mytemp1', 'is_public': True} req = self._post('/templates', json.dumps(body), tenant='second_tenant') result = req.get_response(self.api) self.assertTrue(json.loads(result.body)['is_public']) self.expect_policy_check('list_env_templates') req = self._get('/templates', tenant='first_tenant') result = req.get_response(self.api) self.assertEqual(2, len(json.loads(result.body)['templates']))

commit_message:
Enable OS_LOG_CAPTURE so that logs can be seen (on error)

Enable OS_LOG_CAPTURE so that logs can be seen on error. This
helps to debug issues when a particular test fails on the gate.

Change-Id: Ib66adff0a3864e9bc78d67f09d308f36236f5a5b

commit_message:
testing: Remove comment about looking at patch ports.

The provider networks implementation in OVN still uses OVS patch ports,
but they are not created at the time this document stated.  They are
created dynamically and only when needed by OVN.  This isn't really
important to the testing procedure, so just drop it.

Change-Id: I03ef654902d405c9c9b4d7f96b80eed96a3f3828
Signed-off-by: Russell Bryant <rbryant@redhat.com>

commit_message:
Fix issue in hacking with underscore imports

Hacking rule for underscore imports _() are not working correctly.
It also matches _.* imports like "import _LE"

See review: https://review.openstack.org/#/c/270754/

Closes-bug: 1541780
Change-Id: Ibdef35e1896882a8dfe3165dba989255639e61ba

commit_message:
skeleton version of newton schedule

Add a tool to produce the schedule table, and add a table for newton's
schedule based on when the summit is and the three week period we have
for mitaka between the release and the newton summit.

Change-Id: I4a4a16426b00c5f21a10d0ce9de221d588ee5fe5
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

added_lines: | | | :ref:`m-rf` | | | | +---------------------------+-----------------------------+.. _m-rf: Requirements freeze ------------------- After the mitaka-3 milestone, only critical requirements and constraints changes will be allowed. Freezing our requirements list gives packagers downstream an opportunity to catch up and prepare packages for everything necessary for distributions of the upcoming release. The requirements remain frozen until the stable branches are created, with the release candidates.

commit_message:
rip out search entirely

I haven't been able to restore search to the usual sphinx built-in
implementation, and we want to launch the site. We can launch without
search for now, and add it back later if we decide that's useful.

Change-Id: I0bdda760b18fe3a34c044220c571c64ddec7649a
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>

commit_message:
import a copy of openstackdocstheme

This is a forked copy of openstackdocstheme, which will serve as the
basis for the theme for releases.openstack.org. Rather than try to make
the existing theme work, or "subclass" it, I plan to modify it here in
place. That will avoid issues from future changes upstream by the docs
team, who have their own requirements. I'm checking the whole thing in
in this patch, and will modify it in a follow-up patch, to make clear
what the modifications are.

Change-Id: I3cd9c0e44404447b7c6497f8f9f054a94ec1a46f
Signed-off-by: Doug Hellmann <doug@doughellmann.com>
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/releases refs/changes/20/277620/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD

commit_message:
Switch tempest verify-config usage to avoid bug

This commit will unblock the world breakage caused by the recent
cliff release. This exposes a hole in our constraints usage in
devstack. We need to fix this bug for real in devstack and cliff,
but that will take a few minutes to an hour or so. So let's just
change the usage in the meantime, we can revert this when things
are fixed for real.

Related-Bug: #1543841

Depends-On: Ic63612dc50e064a3a69b88618e394ba17e083c22
Change-Id: I19e477fa5068474bc3471307732f89adaafb2952
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/devstack refs/changes/51/278151/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: tox -revenv -- tempest verify-config -u -r -o $tmp_cfg_file
deleted_lines: tox -revenv -- tempest verify-config -uro $tmp_cfg_file

commit_message:
Using a smarter way to get freezer-api URL

By priority:
    - Getting it from the FREEZER_API_URL parameter in the enabled file
    - Getting it from keystone with the provided endpoint type
    - Getting it from keystone with the 'internal' endpoint type
    - Getting it from keystone with the 'public' endpoint type

Resolves bug: 1541933

Change-Id: I7c369ca192f9c3acf551270382abb2bf231abb38
(cherry picked from commit da9cbb1968436cd038c371d00df47e789b67efec)
git_command: git fetch https://review.opendev.org/openstack/freezer-web-ui refs/changes/10/277810/1 && git format-patch -1 --stdout FETCH_HEAD
added_lines: hardcoded_url = getattr(settings, 'FREEZER_API_URL', None) if hardcoded_url is not None: LOG.warn('Using hardcoded FREEZER_API_URL: {0}'.format(hardcoded_url)) return hardcoded_url e_type = getattr(settings, 'OPENSTACK_ENDPOINT_TYPE', '') endpoint_type_priority = [e_type, ['internal', 'internalURL'], ['public', 'publicURL']] try: catalog = (getattr(request.user, "service_catalog", [])) for c in catalog: if c['name'] == 'freezer': for endpoint_type in endpoint_type_priority: for e in c['endpoints']: if e['interface'] in endpoint_type: return e['url'] raise ValueError('Could no get FREEZER_API_URL from config' ' or Keystone') except Exception: LOG.warn('Could no get FREEZER_API_URL from config or Keystone') action['freezer_action'].get('path_to_backup') or action['freezer_action'].get('restore_abs_path'),
deleted_lines: catalog = (getattr(request.user, "service_catalog", None)) if not catalog: return _get_hardcoded_url() for c in catalog: if c['name'] == 'freezer': for e in c['endpoints']: return e['internalURL'] else: return _get_hardcoded_url() @memoized def _get_hardcoded_url(): """In case freezer is not registered in keystone catalog, look for it in local_settings.py :return: freezer_api_url """ try: LOG.warn('Using hardcoded FREEZER_API_URL at {0}' .format(settings.FREEZER_API_URL)) return getattr(settings, 'FREEZER_API_URL', None) except Exception: LOG.warn('No FREEZER_API_URL was found in local_settings.py') action['freezer_action'].get('path_to_backup') or action['freezer_action'].get('restore_abs_path'),

commit_message:
Set proper z-index value on messages and navbar

The navbar should have been using the built in navbar-fixed-top class
as it is a fixed top navbar.  After added the correct class, the
correct z-index value was added via Bootstrap, then the messages
container simply needed to add a z-index that would appropriately
place it above dropdowns.

The user menu was simply a symptom of the overall problem, where all
the dropdowns in the navbar needed to behave the same way.

The z-index variables of the theme were used, therefore the
incorrect stacking of the messages over the spinner and the modal
were fixed at the same time.

It was noted that the right padding of the messages was using the
incorrect padding variable.  This was corrected.

Closes-bug: #1408640
Co-Authored-By: Diana Whitten <hurgleburgler@gmail.com>
Change-Id: I1d59049d43e74c2a897673307593993f4291da39

deleted_lines: z-index: 9999; top: 20px;
